description: Jun. 4-- GALESBURG-- Court is back in session, although not everyone has gotten the memo. The Illinois Supreme Court announced May 20 that circuit courts would be allowed to resume regular operations June 1, but how courts would handle this action was not specified, aside from that they should follow social distancing measures and find a way to reduce the number of...
text:
Jun. 4\--GALESBURG \-- Court is back in session, although not everyone has
gotten the memo.

The Illinois Supreme Court announced May 20 that circuit courts would be
allowed to resume regular operations June 1, but how courts would handle this
action was not specified, aside from that they should follow social distancing
measures and find a way to reduce the number of people present in courtrooms
and courthouses.

At the Knox County Courthouse, Zoom meetings are now often replacing
traditional in-person court, and a YouTube stream is taking the place of an
in-court audience, for those who choose those options. Still, with a large
number of cases delayed over the past few months, many people are either not
aware or forgetting to show up.

"About half the people are just not showing up to court," Administrative
Justice Scott Shipplett said.

While cases deemed essential were still heard since shutdowns in March brought
courtroom proceedings to a near halt, June 1 opened the floodgates for cases
that have built up over time.

Orders of protection, bail hearings and drug cases were still heard, but many
were not.

"If there was a case where somebody was behind on their credit card bill and
the credit card company wanted to sue them, they just had to wait," Shipplett
said.

What court looks like will differ from the traditional appearance of a court
hearing, if not the format. When Shipplett presides over felony cases, he will
be in his office, and the court reporter will be in hers. The state's attorney
will also be tuning in virtually, while public defenders will be in their
office, sometimes with their clients, or in the hall, where laptop computers
in the witness room can be used to join the meeting.

Circuit Judge Emily Sutton is operating traffic and misdemeanor courts, which
also resumed for the first time in months on June 1, with a mixture of in-
person and Zoom calls. Like Shipplett's courtroom, she has also had issues
with individuals missing their hearings.

"I don't think word has spread that we are back in business, and I think some
of that has to do with the confusion that may be out there because there is no
one size fits all approach," she said of the state's method to reopen courts.

For Monday, Wednesday and Friday traffic and misdemeanor court, different
options are being allowed for those coming in. Those who come to the courtroom
on their date are given the option to return to their cars or even their homes
and dial into court remotely with audio only or audio and video on Zoom.

For those who don't have the technology, or perhaps are not comfortable with
calling into court, a limited number will be allowed into the courtroom
itself, limited to eight at a time. These individuals are given numbers and
called in over time.

Those who do choose to appear in the courtroom must wear masks, and some
chairs have been taped off so that everyone sits at least six feet apart. Pens
are disinfected between uses.

With gatherings in enclosed spaces still encouraged to stay under 10 people,
courtrooms have had to get creative to work within the restrictions. Shipplett
says jury trials will be a great challenge, as jury pools contain 60 to 70
people, and the courthouse is not large enough to space out people of that
volume.

Shipplett says he was told by Knox County Health Department Director Michele
Gabriel that in mid-June, if Illinois moves on to the next phase of its
recovery plan, they may be able to make accommodations in the courthouse and
return to live courtroom hearings. Even then, the judge does not mind the way
court is being done for now.

"I like doing it by Zoom," he said. "It's different, but nobody's getting sick
this way."

___

(c)2020 The Register-Mail, Galesburg, Ill

Visit The Register-Mail, Galesburg, Ill at www.galesburg.com

Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

title: Courts back in session, but no-shows abound [The Register-Mail, Galesburg, Ill.]
html:
Jun. 4--GALESBURG -- Court is back in session, although not everyone has gotten the memo.

The Illinois Supreme Court announced May 20 that circuit courts would be allowed to resume regular operations June 1, but how courts would handle this action was not specified, aside from that they should follow social distancing measures and find a way to reduce the number of people present in courtrooms and courthouses.

At the Knox County Courthouse, Zoom meetings are now often replacing traditional in-person court, and a YouTube stream is taking the place of an in-court audience, for those who choose those options. Still, with a large number of cases delayed over the past few months, many people are either not aware or forgetting to show up.

"About half the people are just not showing up to court," Administrative Justice Scott Shipplett said.

While cases deemed essential were still heard since shutdowns in March brought courtroom proceedings to a near halt, June 1 opened the floodgates for cases that have built up over time.

Orders of protection, bail hearings and drug cases were still heard, but many were not.

"If there was a case where somebody was behind on their credit card bill and the credit card company wanted to sue them, they just had to wait," Shipplett said.

What court looks like will differ from the traditional appearance of a court hearing, if not the format. When Shipplett presides over felony cases, he will be in his office, and the court reporter will be in hers. The state's attorney will also be tuning in virtually, while public defenders will be in their office, sometimes with their clients, or in the hall, where laptop computers in the witness room can be used to join the meeting.

Circuit Judge Emily Sutton is operating traffic and misdemeanor courts, which also resumed for the first time in months on June 1, with a mixture of in-person and Zoom calls. Like Shipplett's courtroom, she has also had issues with individuals missing their hearings.

"I don't think word has spread that we are back in business, and I think some of that has to do with the confusion that may be out there because there is no one size fits all approach," she said of the state's method to reopen courts.

For Monday, Wednesday and Friday traffic and misdemeanor court, different options are being allowed for those coming in. Those who come to the courtroom on their date are given the option to return to their cars or even their homes and dial into court remotely with audio only or audio and video on Zoom.

For those who don't have the technology, or perhaps are not comfortable with calling into court, a limited number will be allowed into the courtroom itself, limited to eight at a time. These individuals are given numbers and called in over time.

Those who do choose to appear in the courtroom must wear masks, and some chairs have been taped off so that everyone sits at least six feet apart. Pens are disinfected between uses.

With gatherings in enclosed spaces still encouraged to stay under 10 people, courtrooms have had to get creative to work within the restrictions. Shipplett says jury trials will be a great challenge, as jury pools contain 60 to 70 people, and the courthouse is not large enough to space out people of that volume.

Shipplett says he was told by Knox County Health Department Director Michele Gabriel that in mid-June, if Illinois moves on to the next phase of its recovery plan, they may be able to make accommodations in the courthouse and return to live courtroom hearings. Even then, the judge does not mind the way court is being done for now.

"I like doing it by Zoom," he said. "It's different, but nobody's getting sick this way."

___

(c)2020 The Register-Mail, Galesburg, Ill

Visit The Register-Mail, Galesburg, Ill at www.galesburg.com

Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.
